cards.name: Sylvan Bounty
cards.text:
Target player gains 8 life.
Basic landcycling {1}{G} ({1}{G}, Discard this card: Search your library for a basic land card, reveal it, put it into your hand, then shuffle your library.)

rulings.text: Unlike the normal cycling ability, basic landcycling doesn't allow you to draw a card. Instead, it lets you search your library for a basic land card. You don't choose the type of basic land card you'll find until you're performing the search. After you choose a basic land card in your library, you reveal it, put it into your hand, then shuffle your library.

Basic landcycling is a form of cycling. Any ability that triggers on a card being cycled also triggers on a card being basic landcycled. Any ability that stops a cycling ability from being activated also stops a basic landcycling ability from being activated.

Basic landcycling is an activated ability. Effects that interact with activated abilities (such as Stifle or Rings of Brighthearth) will interact with basic landcycling. Effects that interact with spells (such as Remove Soul or Faerie Tauntings) will not.
You can choose not to find a basic land card, even if there is one in your library.

cards.originalText:
Target player gains 8 life.
Basic landcycling {1}{G} ({1}{G}, Discard this card: Search your library for a basic land card, reveal it, and put it into your hand. Then shuffle your library.)

cards.name: Voyaging Satyr
cards.text: {T}: Untap target land.
cards.flavor: "None can own the land's bounty. The gods made this world for all to share its riches. And I'm not just saying that because you caught me stealing your fruit."
cards.originalText: {T}: Untap target land.

cards.name: Wild Pair
cards.text: Whenever a creature enters the battlefield, if you cast it from your hand, you may search your library for a creature card with the same total power and toughness and put it onto the battlefield. If you do, shuffle your library.

rulings.text: If you cast a 2/2 Grizzly Bears, for example, you may then search for any creature with total power and toughness 4. It can be 0/4, 1/3, 2/2, or 3/1.

The game checks the power and toughness of the creature that just entered the battlefield as it exists on the battlefield. That might mean it's impossible to get another copy of that same card. For example, a Triskelion on the battlefield is 4/4, but a Triskelion in your library is 1/1. The power and toughness might also have been affected while the triggered ability was on the stack (such as with Giant Growth, Sudden Death, or Ovinize).

If the creature that entered the battlefield has left the battlefield by the time the ability resolves, use the power and toughness of that creature as it last appeared before leaving the battlefield.

cards.originalText: Whenever a creature enters the battlefield, if you cast it from your hand, you may search your library for a creature card with the same total power and toughness and put it onto the battlefield. If you do, shuffle your library.

cards.name: Akroan Hoplite
cards.text: Whenever Akroan Hoplite attacks, it gets +X/+0 until end of turn, where X is the number of attacking creatures you control.
cards.flavor: "Fair fight? How could it be a fair fight? We're Akroans. They're not."

rulings.text: Count the number of attacking creatures you control when the ability resolves to determine the value of X.
Once the ability resolves, the bonus won't change even if the number of attacking creatures you control does.

cards.originalText: Whenever Akroan Hoplite attacks, it gets +X/+0 until end of turn, where X is the number of attacking creatures you control.

cards.name: Ascended Lawmage
cards.text:
Flying
Hexproof (This creature can't be the target of spells or abilities your opponents control.)
cards.flavor: A lawmage's runic script is an act of governance given form: legislation written directly onto the air itself.
cards.originalText:
Flying
Hexproof (This creature can't be the target of spells or abilities your opponents control.)

cards.name: Carnage Gladiator
cards.text:
Whenever a creature blocks, that creature's controller loses 1 life.
{1}{B}{R}: Regenerate Carnage Gladiator.
cards.flavor: Not the foulest or bloodiest act at Rix Maadi by a stretch.

rulings.text: Carnage Gladiator's ability triggers whenever any creature blocks, regardless of who controls that creature or which creature it blocked.
If a creature can block multiple creatures and does so, Carnage Gladiator's ability triggers only once.

cards.originalText:
Whenever a creature blocks, that creature's controller loses 1 life.
{1}{B}{R}: Regenerate Carnage Gladiator.

cards.name: Coiling Oracle
cards.text: When Coiling Oracle enters the battlefield, reveal the top card of your library. If it's a land card, put it onto the battlefield. Otherwise, put that card into your hand.
cards.flavor: Snaking remnants of nature directed by a body of thought and progress, the oracles embody all that is Simic.
cards.originalText: When Coiling Oracle enters the battlefield, reveal the top card of your library. If it's a land card, put it onto the battlefield. Otherwise, put that card into your hand.

cards.name: Dragonlair Spider
cards.text:
Reach
Whenever an opponent casts a spell, create a 1/1 green Insect creature token.
cards.flavor: Swarms thrive in its nest, feeding on leathery bits of discarded wing.

rulings.text: The triggered ability will resolve and the Insect will be created before the spell that caused it to trigger resolves.
The triggered ability won't be affected if the spell that caused it to trigger is countered.

cards.originalText:
Reach
Whenever an opponent casts a spell, put a 1/1 green Insect creature token onto the battlefield.

cards.name: Duskmantle Seer
cards.text:
Flying
At the beginning of your upkeep, each player reveals the top card of their library, loses life equal to that card's converted mana cost, then puts it into their hand.

rulings.text: The loss of life is simultaneous. If this causes both players to end up at 0 or less life, the game will be a draw. In a multiplayer game, players with 0 or less life will lose the game.

The cards put into hands this way are not "drawn." For example, you couldn't reveal a card with miracle put into your hand this way (but it also won't count as the first card you've drawn this turn either).

foreignNames.name: ダスクマントルの予見者

cards.originalText:
Flying
At the beginning of your upkeep, each player reveals the top card of his or her library, loses life equal to that card's converted mana cost, then puts it into his or her hand.

cards.name: Gruul War Chant
cards.text: Attacking creatures you control get +1/+0 and have menace.
cards.flavor:
"We are the heart of the wild, the fire in its eyes, and the howl in its throat. Come, join the battle to which you were born."
—Kroshkar, Gruul shaman
cards.originalText: Attacking creatures you control get +1/+0 and have menace. (They can't be blocked except by two or more creatures.)

cards.name: Juniper Order Ranger
cards.text: Whenever another creature enters the battlefield under your control, put a +1/+1 counter on that creature and a +1/+1 counter on Juniper Order Ranger.
cards.flavor: To protect the alliance between Kjeldor and Yavimaya, they trained in the ways of both.

rulings.text: The creature doesn't enter the battlefield with a +1/+1 counter on it. It enters the battlefield, then the ability triggers. If either that creature or Juniper Order Ranger leaves the battlefield before the ability resolves, the remaining creature will still get a +1/+1 counter.

foreignNames.name: 柏槙教団のレインジャー

cards.originalText: Whenever another creature enters the battlefield under your control, put a +1/+1 counter on that creature and a +1/+1 counter on Juniper Order Ranger.

cards.name: Pharika's Mender
cards.text: When Pharika's Mender enters the battlefield, you may return target creature or enchantment card from your graveyard to your hand.
cards.flavor: "The direst venom becomes a panacea under Pharika's guidance. I bring it to the worthy, clinging at the edge of the abyss."
cards.originalText: When Pharika's Mender enters the battlefield, you may return target creature or enchantment card from your graveyard to your hand.

cards.name: Shipwreck Singer
cards.text:
Flying
{1}{U}: Target creature an opponent controls attacks this turn if able.
{1}{B}, {T}: Attacking creatures get -1/-1 until end of turn.

rulings.text: The controller of each attacking creature still chooses which player or planeswalker that creature attacks.

If, during a player's declare attackers step, a creature is tapped, is affected by a spell or ability that says it can't attack, or hasn't been under that player's control continuously since the turn began (and doesn't have haste), then it doesn't attack. If there's a cost associated with having a creature attack, the player isn't forced to pay that cost, so it doesn't have to attack in that case either.
The last ability affects creatures that are already attacking when it resolves. Activating it before combat won't affect any creatures that attack later that turn.

cards.originalText:
Flying
{1}{U}: Target creature an opponent controls attacks this turn if able.
{1}{B}, {T}: Attacking creatures get -1/-1 until end of turn.

cards.name: Stormchaser Chimera
cards.text:
Flying
{2}{U}{R}: Scry 1, then reveal the top card of your library. Stormchaser Chimera gets +X/+0 until end of turn, where X is that card's converted mana cost. (To scry 1, look at the top card of your library, then you may put that card on the bottom of your library.)
cards.originalText:
Flying
{2}{U}{R}: Scry 1, then reveal the top card of your library. Stormchaser Chimera gets +X/+0 until end of turn, where X is that card's converted mana cost. (To scry 1, look at the top card of your library, then you may put that card on the bottom of your library.)

cards.name: Bronze Sable
cards.flavor:
The Champion stood alone between the horde of the Returned and the shrine to Karametra, cutting down scores among hundreds. She would have been overcome if not for the aid of the temple guardians whom Karametra awakened.
—The Theriad

cards.text:

cards.flavor:
"Use everything. Iron, rust, scrap . . .  even the ground must join our cause."
—Ezuri, renegade leader

cards.name: Horn of Greed
cards.text: Whenever a player plays a land, that player draws a card.
cards.flavor:
"Rath grows, and I am nourished."
—Volrath

rulings.text: Playing a land will trigger it, but putting a land onto the battlefield as part of an effect will not.

cards.originalText: Whenever a player plays a land, that player draws a card.

cards.name: Kitesail
cards.text:
Equipped creature gets +1/+0 and has flying.
Equip {2} ({2}: Attach to target creature you control. Equip only as a sorcery.)
cards.flavor: Kitesailing is a way of life—and without practice, the end of it.
cards.originalText:
Equipped creature gets +1/+0 and has flying.
Equip {2} ({2}: Attach to target creature you control. Equip only as a sorcery.)

cards.name: Opaline Unicorn
cards.text: {T}: Add one mana of any color.
cards.flavor: Purphoros once loved Nylea, the god of the hunt. His passion inspired his most astounding works of art.
cards.originalText: {T}: Add one mana of any color to your mana pool.

cards.name: Platinum Angel
cards.text:
Flying
You can't lose the game and your opponents can't win the game.
cards.flavor: She is the apex of the artificer's craft, the spirit of the divine called out of base metal.

rulings.text: Effects that say the game is a draw, such as the _Legends_(TM) card Divine Intervention, are not affected by Platinum Angel. They'll still work.

You can concede a game while Platinum Angel on the battlefield. A concession causes you to leave the game, which then causes you to lose the game (Once you concede, you no longer control a Platinum Angel, so its ability can't prevent you from losing the game).

No game effect can cause you to lose the game or cause any opponent to win the game while you control Platinum Angel. It doesn't matter whether you have 0 or less life, you're forced to draw a card while your library is empty, you have ten or more poison counters, you're dealt combat damage by Phage the Untouchable, your opponent has Mortal Combat with twenty or more creature cards in their graveyard, or so on. You keep playing.

Other circumstances can still cause you to lose the game, however. You will lose a game if you concede, if you're penalized with a Game Loss or a Match Loss during a sanctioned tournament due to a DCI rules infraction, or if your _Magic Online_(R) game clock runs out of time.
If you control Platinum Angel in a Two-Headed Giant game, your team can't lose the game and the opposing team can't win the game.

cards.originalText:
Flying
You can't lose the game and your opponents can't win the game.

cards.name: Psychosis Crawler
cards.text:
Psychosis Crawler's power and toughness are each equal to the number of cards in your hand.
Whenever you draw a card, each opponent loses 1 life.
cards.flavor:
"If that brain can't figure out the secret of the serum, then add more brains."
—Rhmir, Hand of the Augur

rulings.text: If an effect causes you to draw multiple cards, Psychosis Crawler will trigger that many times.

cards.originalText:
Psychosis Crawler's power and toughness are each equal to the number of cards in your hand.
Whenever you draw a card, each opponent loses 1 life.

cards.name: Runed Servitor
cards.text: When Runed Servitor dies, each player draws a card.
cards.flavor: Scholars had puzzled for centuries over the ruins at Tal Terig. Its secrets had always lived within one rune-carved head.
cards.originalText: When Runed Servitor dies, each player draws a card.

cards.name: Dread Statuary
cards.text:
{T}: Add {C}.
{4}: Dread Statuary becomes a 4/2 Golem artifact creature until end of turn. It's still a land.
cards.flavor: The last reliable landmark in Tazeem just walked away.

rulings.text: A land that becomes a creature may be affected by "summoning sickness." You can't attack with it or use any of its {T} abilities (including its mana abilities) unless it began your most recent turn on the battlefield under your control. Note that summoning sickness cares about when that permanent came under your control, not when it became a creature.

When a land becomes a creature, that doesn't count as having a creature enter the battlefield. The permanent was already on the battlefield; it only changed its types. Abilities that trigger whenever a creature enters the battlefield won't trigger.

cards.originalText:
{T}: Add {C} to your mana pool.
{4}: Dread Statuary becomes a 4/2 Golem artifact creature until end of turn. It's still a land.

cards.name: Evolving Wilds
cards.text: {T}, Sacrifice Evolving Wilds: Search your library for a basic land card, put it onto the battlefield tapped, then shuffle your library.
cards.flavor: Without the interfering hands of civilization, nature will always shape itself to its own needs.
cards.originalText: {T}, Sacrifice Evolving Wilds: Search your library for a basic land card and put it onto the battlefield tapped. Then shuffle your library.

cards.name: Exotic Orchard
cards.text: {T}: Add one mana of any color that a land an opponent controls could produce.
cards.flavor:
"It was a strange morning. When we awoke, we found our trees transformed. We didn't know whether to water them or polish them."
—Pulan, Bant orchardist

rulings.text: The colors of mana are white, blue, black, red, and green. Exotic Orchard can't be tapped for colorless mana, even if a land an opponent controls could produce colorless mana.

Exotic Orchard checks the effects of all mana-producing abilities of lands your opponents control, but it doesn't check their costs. For example, Vivid Crag has the ability "{T}, Remove a charge counter from Vivid Crag: Add one mana of any color." If an opponent controls Vivid Crag and you control Exotic Orchard, you can tap Exotic Orchard for any color of mana. It doesn't matter whether Vivid Crag has a charge counter on it, and it doesn't matter whether it's untapped.

When determining what colors of mana your opponents' lands could produce, Exotic Orchard takes into account any applicable replacement effects that would apply to those lands' mana abilities (such as Contamination's effect, for example). If there are more than one, consider them in any possible order.

Exotic Orchard doesn't care about any restrictions or riders your opponents' lands (such as Ancient Ziggurat or Hall of the Bandit Lord) put on the mana they produce. It just cares about colors of mana.

Lands that produce mana based only on what other lands "could produce" won't help each other unless some other land allows one of them to actually produce some type of mana. For example, if you control an Exotic Orchard and your opponent controls an Exotic Orchard and a Reflecting Pool, none of those lands would produce mana if their mana abilities were activated. On the other hand, if you control a Forest and an Exotic Orchard, and your opponent controls an Exotic Orchard and a Reflecting Pool, then each of those lands can be tapped to produce {G}. Your opponent's Exotic Orchard can produce {G} because you control a Forest. Your Exotic Orchard and your opponent's Reflecting Pool can each produce {G} because your opponent's Exotic Orchard can produce {G}.

cards.originalText: {T}: Add to your mana pool one mana of any color that a land an opponent controls could produce.

cards.name: Rogue's Passage
cards.text:
{T}: Add {C}.
{4}, {T}: Target creature can't be blocked this turn.
cards.flavor: Rumors quickly spread among thieves about a labyrinth without walls and a prize beyond all measures of worth.

rulings.text: Activating the second ability of Rogue's Passage after a creature has become blocked won't cause it to become unblocked.

cards.originalText:
{T}: Add {C} to your mana pool.
{4}, {T}: Target creature can't be blocked this turn.

cards.name: Shimmering Grotto
cards.text:
{T}: Add {C}.
{1}, {T}: Add one mana of any color.
cards.flavor: Untold riches await those who forsake the bustling world to search the secret, silent places.
cards.originalText:
{T}: Add {C} to your mana pool.
{1}, {T}: Add one mana of any color to your mana pool.

cards.name: Kaya, Ghost Assassin
cards.text:
0: Exile Kaya, Ghost Assassin or up to one target creature. Return that card to the battlefield under its owner's control at the beginning of your next upkeep. You lose 2 life.
−1: Each opponent loses 2 life and you gain 2 life.
−2: Each opponent discards a card and you draw a card.

rulings.text: You choose whether or not to target a creature as you activate the first ability. If you chose a target creature, you choose whether to exile Kaya or that creature as the ability resolves. If you chose a creature and that creature is no longer a legal target as the ability tries to resolve, the ability doesn't resolve and none of its effects happen. You won't exile Kaya or lose 2 life.

If you didn't choose a target creature for the first ability, and Kaya isn't on the battlefield as the ability resolves, you'll just lose 2 life. No card will be exiled or returned to the battlefield.
As the last ability resolves, each opponent will choose a card to discard and set it aside. Then all those cards are revealed and discarded simultaneously.

foreignNames.name: 幽（ゆう）霊（れい）暗（あん）殺（さつ）者（しゃ）、ケイヤ

cards.originalText:
0: Exile Kaya, Ghost Assassin or up to one target creature. Return that card to the battlefield under its owner's control at the beginning of your next upkeep. You lose 2 life.
−1: Each opponent loses 2 life and you gain 2 life.
−2: Each opponent discards a card and you draw a card.

cards.name: Artisan of Kozilek
cards.text:
When you cast this spell, you may return target creature card from your graveyard to the battlefield.
Annihilator 2 (Whenever this creature attacks, defending player sacrifices two permanents.)

rulings.text: Annihilator abilities trigger and resolve during the declare attackers step. The defending player chooses and sacrifices the required number of permanents before they declare blockers. Any creatures sacrificed this way won't be able to block.

If a creature with annihilator is attacking a planeswalker, and the defending player chooses to sacrifice that planeswalker, the attacking creature continues to attack. It may be blocked. If it isn't blocked, it simply won't deal combat damage to anything.

cards.originalText:
When you cast Artisan of Kozilek, you may return target creature card from your graveyard to the battlefield.
Annihilator 2 (Whenever this creature attacks, defending player sacrifices two permanents.)

cards.name: Afterlife
cards.text: Destroy target creature. It can't be regenerated. Its controller creates a 1/1 white Spirit creature token with flying.
cards.originalText: Destroy target creature. It can't be regenerated. Its controller puts a 1/1 white Spirit creature token with flying onto the battlefield.

cards.name: Akroma's Vengeance
cards.text:
Destroy all artifacts, creatures, and enchantments.
Cycling {3} ({3}, Discard this card: Draw a card.)
cards.flavor: Ixidor had only to imagine their ruin and Akroma made it so.

rulings.text: Cycling is an activated ability. Effects that interact with activated abilities (such as Stifle or Rings of Brighthearth) will interact with cycling. Effects that interact with spells (such as Remove Soul or Faerie Tauntings) will not.

cards.originalText:
Destroy all artifacts, creatures, and enchantments.
Cycling {3} ({3}, Discard this card: Draw a card.)

cards.name: Alliance of Arms
cards.text: Join forces — Starting with you, each player may pay any amount of mana. Each player creates X 1/1 white Soldier creature tokens, where X is the total amount of mana paid this way.
cards.originalText: Join forces — Starting with you, each player may pay any amount of mana. Each player puts X 1/1 white Soldier creature tokens onto the battlefield, where X is the total amount of mana paid this way.

cards.name: Angelic Arbiter
cards.text:
Flying
Each opponent who cast a spell this turn can't attack with creatures.
Each opponent who attacked with a creature this turn can't cast spells.

rulings.text: During your turn, Angelic Arbiter's abilities have no effect on the game.

During an opponent's turn, that opponent may either cast spells or attack with creatures, but not both (assuming that Angelic Arbiter is on the battlefield for the entirety of that turn). The player may perform other actions, such as activating abilities and playing lands.

If Angelic Arbiter leaves the battlefield during an opponent's turn, its abilities cease to affect the game. For example, if an opponent casts Doom Blade to destroy Angelic Arbiter, that player may then attack with creatures.

If Angelic Arbiter enters the battlefield during an opponent's turn, its abilities take actions that player performed earlier in the turn into account, even though it wasn't on the battlefield at the time. For example, if an opponent casts a spell, then you use Leyline of Anticipation's ability to cast Angelic Arbiter as though it had flash, that player won't be able to attack with creatures that turn.
Angelic Arbiter's last ability applies if an opponent attacked with at least one creature during the current turn.

cards.originalText:
Flying
Each opponent who cast a spell this turn can't attack with creatures.
Each opponent who attacked with a creature this turn can't cast spells.

cards.name: Arbiter of Knollridge
cards.text:
Vigilance
When Arbiter of Knollridge enters the battlefield, each player's life total becomes the highest life total among all players.
cards.flavor: Though giants are mortal, they live so long and on such a grand scale that many small folk don't believe they ever truly die.

rulings.text: Abilities that trigger when a player gains life may trigger as a result of this ability.

In other multiplayer formats, each player's life total is set to the highest life total within their range of influence. These changes happen at the same time. For example, if each player has a range of influence of one, and the players in the game are Alice (4 life), Barry (8 life), Carrie (11 life), and Doug (7 life), in that order, then Alice's life total will become 8 and Barry and Doug's life totals will each become 11.

In a Two-Headed Giant game, each team chooses one person on that team to gain the appropriate amount of life. This basically means that the triggered ability will set the life total of each team to that of the team with the highest life total.

foreignNames.name: ノールリッジの裁き人

cards.originalText:
Vigilance
When Arbiter of Knollridge enters the battlefield, each player's life total becomes the highest life total among all players.

cards.name: Archangel of Strife
cards.text:
Flying
As Archangel of Strife enters the battlefield, each player chooses war or peace.
Creatures controlled by players who chose war get +3/+0.
Creatures controlled by players who chose peace get +0/+3.

rulings.text: Archangel of Strife's second and third abilities are linked. Similarly, its second and fourth abilities are linked. The bonus a player's creatures get depends only on the choice that player made when Archangel of Strife entered the battlefield.
The active player chooses war or peace first, followed by each other player in turn order. Each player will know what previous players chose when making their choice.
Archangel of Strife's bonuses apply immediately. Depending on your choice, Archangel of Strife will enter the battlefield as either a 9/6 or 6/9 creature.
If there are two Archangels of Strife on the battlefield, and you choose war for one and peace for the other, your creatures get +3/+3.
As soon as Archangel of Strife leaves the battlefield, the bonus stops applying. If it returns to the battlefield, players will be able to make new choices.

cards.originalText:
Flying
As Archangel of Strife enters the battlefield, each player chooses war or peace.
Creatures controlled by players who chose war get +3/+0.
Creatures controlled by players who chose peace get +0/+3.

cards.name: Austere Command
cards.text:
Choose two —
• Destroy all artifacts.
• Destroy all enchantments.
• Destroy all creatures with converted mana cost 3 or less.
• Destroy all creatures with converted mana cost 4 or greater.

rulings.text: Each of the chosen modes happens sequentially. If a permanent has an ability that triggers whenever it or another permanent is destroyed, it will see permanents destroyed at the same time as it or before it, but not permanents destroyed by later modes.

If the first and third modes are chosen, an artifact creature with converted mana cost 3 or less will have to be regenerated twice to survive. This is because the modes happen sequentially, and the regeneration "shield" is used up by the first one. (A similar thing happens with most of the other combinations.)

If a card is exiled "until" another permanent leaves the battlefield, the exiled card returns to the battlefield immediately after that permanent leaves the battlefield during Austere Command's resolution, and it may be destroyed by a later mode.

cards.originalText: Choose two — Destroy all artifacts; or destroy all enchantments; or destroy all creatures with converted mana cost 3 or less; or destroy all creatures with converted mana cost 4 or greater.

cards.name: Bathe in Light
cards.text: Radiance — Choose a color. Target creature and each other creature that shares a color with it gain protection from the chosen color until end of turn.
cards.flavor: "Truth shines even in darkness. Those who march on the side of truth walk always in righteous light."

rulings.text: The color you choose as the spell resolves has nothing to do with the color or colors shared by the affected creatures.
All creatures that share a color are affected, even your own.

A creature "shares a color" with any creature that is at least one of its colors. For example, a green-white creature shares a color with creatures that are green, white, green-white, red-white, black-green, and so on.
If it targets a colorless creature, it doesn't affect any other creatures. A colorless creature shares a color with nothing, not even other colorless creatures.
You check which creatures share a color with the target when the spell resolves.
Only one creature is targeted. If that creature leaves the battlefield or otherwise becomes an illegal target, the entire spell doesn't resolve. No other creatures are affected.

cards.originalText: Radiance — Choose a color. Target creature and each other creature that shares a color with it gain protection from the chosen color until end of turn.

cards.name: Celestial Force
cards.text: At the beginning of each upkeep, you gain 3 life.
cards.flavor:
"Wishing upon only one star seems like a failure of imagination."
—Vish Kal, Blood Arbiter

rulings.text: In a Two-Headed Giant game, this ability triggers once at the beginning of each team's upkeep.

cards.originalText: At the beginning of each upkeep, you gain 3 life.

cards.name: Congregate
cards.text: Target player gains 2 life for each creature on the battlefield.
cards.flavor:
"In the gathering there is strength for all who founder, renewal for all who languish, love for all who sing."
—Song of All, canto 642

rulings.text: Creatures are counted during resolution.

cards.originalText: Target player gains 2 life for each creature on the battlefield.

cards.name: Crescendo of War
cards.text:
At the beginning of each upkeep, put a strife counter on Crescendo of War.
Attacking creatures get +1/+0 for each strife counter on Crescendo of War.
Blocking creatures you control get +1/+0 for each strife counter on Crescendo of War.

rulings.text: In a Two-Headed Giant game, the first ability triggers once during each team's upkeep.

foreignNames.name: Montée en crescendo de la guerre

cards.originalText:
At the beginning of each upkeep, put a strife counter on Crescendo of War.
Attacking creatures get +1/+0 for each strife counter on Crescendo of War.
Blocking creatures you control get +1/+0 for each strife counter on Crescendo of War.

cards.name: False Prophet
cards.text: When False Prophet dies, exile all creatures.
cards.flavor: "You lived for Serra's love. Will you not die for it?"

rulings.text: False Prophet only exiles creatures, which means only creature permanents which are on the battlefield. It won't exile itself since it is already in the graveyard.

cards.originalText: When False Prophet is put into a graveyard from the battlefield, exile all creatures.

cards.name: Ghostly Prison
cards.text: Creatures can't attack you unless their controller pays {2} for each creature they control that's attacking you.
cards.flavor:
"May the memory of our fallen heroes ensnare the violent hearts of lesser men."
—Great Threshold of Monserkat inscription

rulings.text: In the Two-Headed Giant format, you still only have to pay once per creature.
Unless some effect explicitly says otherwise, a creature that can't attack you can still attack a planeswalker you control.

cards.originalText: Creatures can't attack you unless their controller pays {2} for each creature he or she controls that's attacking you.

cards.name: Hour of Reckoning
cards.text:
Convoke (Your creatures can help cast this spell. Each creature you tap while casting this spell pays for {1} or one mana of that creature's color.)
Destroy all nontoken creatures.
cards.flavor:
"Ravnica, like a hedge, must be pruned, leaving only leaves of verdant uniformity."
—Niszka, Selesnya evangel

rulings.text: The rules for convoke have changed slightly since it last appeared in an expansion. Previously, convoke reduced the cost to cast a spell. Under current rules, you tap creatures at the same time you pay the spell's costs. Tapping a creature this way is simply another way to pay.
Convoke doesn't change a spell's mana cost or converted mana cost.

When calculating a spell's total cost, include any alternative costs, additional costs, or anything else that increases or reduces the cost to cast the spell. Convoke applies after the total cost is calculated.
Because convoke isn't an alternative cost, it can be used in conjunction with alternative costs.
Tapping a multicolored creature using convoke will pay for {1} or one mana of your choice of any of that creature's colors.

When using convoke to cast a spell with {X} in its mana cost, first choose the value for X. That choice, plus any cost increases or decreases, will determine the spell's total cost. Then you can tap creatures you control to help pay that cost. For example, if you cast Chord of Calling (a spell with convoke and mana cost {X}{G}{G}{G}) and choose X to be 3, the total cost is {3}{G}{G}{G}. If you tap two green creatures and two red creatures, you'll have to pay {1}{G}.

If a creature you control has a mana ability with {T} in the cost, activating that ability while casting a spell with convoke will result in the creature being tapped when you pay the spell's costs. You won't be able to tap it again for convoke. Similarly, if you sacrifice a creature to activate a mana ability while casting a spell with convoke, that creature won't be on the battlefield when you pay the spell's costs, so you won't be able to tap it for convoke.

cards.originalText:
Convoke (Each creature you tap while casting this spell reduces its cost by {1} or by one mana of that creature's color.)
Destroy all nontoken creatures.

cards.name: Jötun Grunt
cards.text: Cumulative upkeep—Put two cards from a single graveyard on the bottom of their owner's library. (At the beginning of your upkeep, put an age counter on this permanent, then sacrifice it unless you pay its upkeep cost for each age counter on it.)

rulings.text: When paying Jötun Grunt's cumulative upkeep, you may choose a different graveyard for each age counter. For example, if it has three age counters on it, you may put four cards from your graveyard on the bottom of your library and two cards from your opponent's graveyard on the bottom of their library. However, you can't put five cards from your graveyard on the bottom of your library and one card from your opponent's graveyard on the bottom of their library.

cards.originalText: Cumulative upkeep—Put two cards from a single graveyard on the bottom of their owner's library. (At the beginning of your upkeep, put an age counter on this permanent, then sacrifice it unless you pay its upkeep cost for each age counter on it.)

cards.name: Journey to Nowhere
cards.text:
When Journey to Nowhere enters the battlefield, exile target creature.
When Journey to Nowhere leaves the battlefield, return the exiled card to the battlefield under its owner's control.

rulings.text: If Journey to Nowhere leaves the battlefield before its first ability has resolved, its second ability will trigger and do nothing. Then its first ability will resolve and exile the targeted creature forever.

cards.originalText:
When Journey to Nowhere enters the battlefield, exile target creature.
When Journey to Nowhere leaves the battlefield, return the exiled card to the battlefield under its owner's control.

cards.name: Lightkeeper of Emeria
cards.text:
Multikicker {W} (You may pay an additional {W} any number of times as you cast this spell.)
Flying
When Lightkeeper of Emeria enters the battlefield, you gain 2 life for each time it was kicked.

foreignNames.name: Guardiana de la luz de Emeria

cards.originalText:
Multikicker {W} (You may pay an additional {W} any number of times as you cast this spell.)
Flying
When Lightkeeper of Emeria enters the battlefield, you gain 2 life for each time it was kicked.

cards.name: Martyr's Bond
cards.text: Whenever Martyr's Bond or another nonland permanent you control is put into a graveyard from the battlefield, each opponent sacrifices a permanent that shares a card type with it.
cards.flavor:
"Our lives are connected by divine law. The truth of this will be made evident in time."
—Zedruu the Greathearted

rulings.text: If Martyr's Bond and other nonland permanents are put into the graveyard from the battlefield at the same time, Martyr's Bond will trigger for itself and each of those other nonland permanents.

Each opponent must sacrifice only one permanent for each trigger, even if the nonland permanent you controlled that went to the graveyard had multiple types. For example, if an artifact creature you control is put into a graveyard from the battlefield, each opponent sacrifices exactly one artifact or creature, and that permanent doesn't need to be an artifact creature.

cards.originalText: Whenever Martyr's Bond or another nonland permanent you control is put into a graveyard from the battlefield, each opponent sacrifices a permanent that shares a card type with it.

cards.name: Monk Realist
cards.text: When Monk Realist enters the battlefield, destroy target enchantment.
cards.flavor: "We plant the seeds of doubt to harvest the crop of wisdom."
cards.originalText: When Monk Realist enters the battlefield, destroy target enchantment.

cards.name: Mother of Runes
cards.text: {T}: Target creature you control gains protection from the color of your choice until end of turn.
cards.flavor: "My family protects all families."
cards.originalText: {T}: Target creature you control gains protection from the color of your choice until end of turn.

cards.name: Oblation
cards.text: The owner of target nonland permanent shuffles it into their library, then draws two cards.
cards.flavor: "A richer people could give more but they could never give as much."
cards.originalText: The owner of target nonland permanent shuffles it into his or her library, then draws two cards.

cards.name: Oblivion Ring
cards.text:
When Oblivion Ring enters the battlefield, exile another target nonland permanent.
When Oblivion Ring leaves the battlefield, return the exiled card to the battlefield under its owner's control.

rulings.text: If Oblivion Ring leaves the battlefield before its first ability has resolved, its second ability will trigger and do nothing. Then its first ability will resolve and exile the targeted nonland permanent forever.

If there are no nonland permanents on the battlefield other than an Oblivion Ring, and the card it exiled was another Oblivion Ring, casting a third Oblivion Ring will result in an involuntary infinite loop that will end the game in a draw (unless someone chooses to break it by putting another nonland permanent onto the battlefield or destroying one of the Oblivion Rings, for example).

If the exiled card is an Aura, that card's owner chooses what it will enchant as it comes back onto the battlefield. An Aura put onto the battlefield this way doesn't target anything, but the Aura's enchant ability restricts what it can be attached to. If the Aura can't legally be attached to anything, it remains exiled forever.

Auras attached to the exiled permanent will be put into their owners' graveyards. Equipment attached to the exiled permanent will become unattached and remain on the battlefield. Any counters on the exiled permanent will cease to exist.

cards.originalText:
When Oblivion Ring enters the battlefield, exile another target nonland permanent.
When Oblivion Ring leaves the battlefield, return the exiled card to the battlefield under its owner's control.

cards.name: Orim's Thunder
cards.text:
Kicker {R} (You may pay an additional {R} as you cast this spell.)
Destroy target artifact or enchantment. If this spell was kicked, it deals damage equal to that permanent's converted mana cost to target creature.
cards.originalText:
Kicker {R} (You may pay an additional {R} as you cast this spell.)
Destroy target artifact or enchantment. If Orim's Thunder was kicked, it deals damage equal to that permanent's converted mana cost to target creature.

cards.name: Path to Exile
cards.text: Exile target creature. Its controller may search their library for a basic land card, put that card onto the battlefield tapped, then shuffle their library.

rulings.text: If the targeted creature becomes an illegal target by the time Path to Exile would resolve, the entire spell doesn't resolve. The creature's controller won't search for a basic land card.
The controller of the exiled creature isn't required to search their library for a basic land. If that player doesn't, the player won't shuffle their library.

cards.originalText: Exile target creature. Its controller may search his or her library for a basic land card, put that card onto the battlefield tapped, then shuffle his or her library.

cards.name: Pollen Lullaby
cards.text: Prevent all combat damage that would be dealt this turn. Clash with an opponent. If you win, creatures that player controls don't untap during the player's next untap step. (Each clashing player reveals the top card of their library, then puts that card on the top or bottom. A player wins if their card had a higher converted mana cost.)
cards.originalText: Prevent all combat damage that would be dealt this turn. Clash with an opponent. If you win, creatures that player controls don't untap during the player's next untap step. (Each clashing player reveals the top card of his or her library, then puts that card on the top or bottom. A player wins if his or her card had a higher converted mana cost.)

cards.name: Prison Term
cards.text:
Enchant creature
Enchanted creature can't attack or block, and its activated abilities can't be activated.
Whenever a creature enters the battlefield under an opponent's control, you may attach Prison Term to that creature.

rulings.text: The last ability works only if Prison Term is already on the battlefield. You may move it from the creature it's currently enchanting onto the new creature.
Activated abilities contain a colon. They're generally written "[Cost]: [Effect]." Some keywords are activated abilities and will have colons in their reminder text.

cards.originalText:
Enchant creature
Enchanted creature can't attack or block, and its activated abilities can't be activated.
Whenever a creature enters the battlefield under an opponent's control, you may attach Prison Term to that creature.

cards.name: Return to Dust
cards.text: Exile target artifact or enchantment. If you cast this spell during your main phase, you may exile up to one other target artifact or enchantment.
cards.flavor: Some timelines forever fray, branch, and intermingle. Others end abruptly.

rulings.text: Regardless of when Return to Dust is cast, its controller may choose one target or two targets. It can always be cast even if there's only one legal target. If it's cast at a time other than its controller's main phase and a second target is chosen, nothing will happen to that target.

cards.originalText: Exile target artifact or enchantment. If you cast this spell during your main phase, you may exile up to one other target artifact or enchantment.

cards.name: Righteous Cause
cards.text: Whenever a creature attacks, you gain 1 life.
cards.flavor:
"Until the world unites in vengeful fury and Phage is destroyed, I will not stay my hand."
—Akroma, angelic avenger
cards.originalText: Whenever a creature attacks, you gain 1 life.

cards.name: Serra Angel
cards.text: Flying, vigilance
cards.flavor: Perfect justice in service of a perfect will.
cards.originalText: Flying, vigilance

cards.name: Shattered Angel
cards.text:
Flying
Whenever a land enters the battlefield under an opponent's control, you may gain 3 life.
cards.flavor: She preaches the blessings of the Machine Orthodoxy.
cards.originalText:
Flying
Whenever a land enters the battlefield under an opponent's control, you may gain 3 life.

cards.name: Soul Snare
cards.text: {W}, Sacrifice Soul Snare: Exile target creature that's attacking you or a planeswalker you control.
cards.flavor:
"Body and spirit are sworn enemies. They will take any excuse to be rid of each other."
—Tariel, Reckoner of Souls
cards.originalText: {W}, Sacrifice Soul Snare: Exile target creature that's attacking you or a planeswalker you control.

cards.name: Spurnmage Advocate
cards.text: {T}: Return two target cards from an opponent's graveyard to their hand. Destroy target attacking creature.
cards.flavor: "Our unity humbles our foes."

rulings.text: The ability is not countered if both cards are missing from the graveyard on resolution and the creature target is there. This makes it possible to have two Spurnmage Advocates both target the same two cards and end up destroying two creatures.
You can't activate this ability unless a single opponent has at least two cards in their graveyard to target.

cards.originalText: {T}: Return two target cards from an opponent's graveyard to his or her hand. Destroy target attacking creature.

cards.name: Storm Herd
cards.text: Create X 1/1 white Pegasus creature tokens with flying, where X is your life total.
cards.flavor:
"When you hear thunder on a cloudless day, take cover and brace for the coming of the storm herd."
—Skotov, Tin Street basket vendor
cards.originalText: Put X 1/1 white Pegasus creature tokens with flying onto the battlefield, where X is your life total.

cards.name: Voice of All
cards.text:
Flying
As Voice of All enters the battlefield, choose a color.
Voice of All has protection from the chosen color.
cards.originalText:
Flying
As Voice of All enters the battlefield, choose a color. 
Voice of All has protection from the chosen color.

cards.name: Vow of Duty
cards.text:
Enchant creature
Enchanted creature gets +2/+2, has vigilance, and can't attack you or a planeswalker you control.
cards.flavor:
"I prefer loyalty to be a matter of respect, not of magic. But one does what one must."
—Kaalia of the Vast
cards.originalText:
Enchant creature
Enchanted creature gets +2/+2, has vigilance, and can't attack you or a planeswalker you control.

cards.name: Wall of Omens
cards.text:
Defender
When Wall of Omens enters the battlefield, draw a card.
cards.flavor:
"I search for a vision of Zendikar that does not include the Eldrazi."
—Expedition journal entry
cards.originalText:
Defender
When Wall of Omens enters the battlefield, draw a card.

cards.name: Windborn Muse
cards.text:
Flying
Creatures can't attack you unless their controller pays {2} for each creature they control that's attacking you.
cards.flavor:
"Her voice is justice, clear and relentless."
—Akroma, angelic avenger

rulings.text: If you have more than one of these on the battlefield, the cost is cumulative.
In the Two-Headed Giant format, you still only have to pay once per creature.
Unless some effect explicitly says otherwise, a creature that can't attack you can still attack a planeswalker you control.

cards.originalText:
Flying
Creatures can't attack you unless their controller pays {2} for each creature he or she controls that's attacking you.

cards.name: Aethersnipe
cards.text:
When Aethersnipe enters the battlefield, return target nonland permanent to its owner's hand.
Evoke {1}{U}{U} (You may cast this spell for its evoke cost. If you do, it's sacrificed when it enters the battlefield.)

rulings.text: If you cast this card for its evoke cost, you may put the sacrifice trigger and the regular enters-the-battlefield trigger on the stack in either order. The one put on the stack last will resolve first.

cards.originalText:
When Æthersnipe enters the battlefield, return target nonland permanent to its owner's hand.
Evoke {1}{U}{U} (You may cast this spell for its evoke cost. If you do, it's sacrificed when it enters the battlefield.)

cards.name: Brainstorm
cards.text: Draw three cards, then put two cards from your hand on top of your library in any order.
cards.flavor:
"I see more than others do because I know where to look."
—Saprazzan vizier

rulings.text: You draw three cards and put two cards back all while Brainstorm is resolving. Nothing can happen between the two, and no player may choose to take actions.

cards.originalText: Draw three cards, then put two cards from your hand on top of your library in any order.

cards.name: Chromeshell Crab
cards.text:
Morph {4}{U} (You may cast this card face down as a 2/2 creature for {3}. Turn it face up any time for its morph cost.)
When Chromeshell Crab is turned face up, you may exchange control of target creature you control and target creature an opponent controls.

rulings.text: You choose the two target creatures when the triggered ability is put onto the stack. You do not have to choose Chromeshell Crab. You choose whether or not to do the exchange on resolution.
The exchange fails if either target is not still on the battlefield at that time.
The exchange fails if either you no longer control your creature or the other creature is now controlled by you.
The creatures can't attack until you start a turn with them under your control. So you can't swap and then attack.
The trigger occurs when you use the Morph ability to turn the card face up, or when an effect turns it face up. It will not trigger on being revealed or on leaving the battlefield.

cards.originalText:
Morph {4}{U} (You may cast this face down as a 2/2 creature for {3}. Turn it face up any time for its morph cost.)
When Chromeshell Crab is turned face up, you may exchange control of target creature you control and target creature an opponent controls.

cards.name: Conundrum Sphinx
cards.text:
Flying
Whenever Conundrum Sphinx attacks, each player chooses a card name. Then each player reveals the top card of their library. If the card a player revealed has the name they chose, that player puts it into their hand. If it doesn't, that player puts it on the bottom of their library.

rulings.text: First the player whose turn it is names a card, then each other player in turn order does the same. Then each player reveals the top card of their library at the same time.

If a card a player reveals this way is the card that particular player named, they must put it into their hand. Otherwise, they must put it on the bottom of their library, even if it's the card a different player named. In no cases can a player leave the revealed card on top of their library.

cards.originalText:
Flying
Whenever Conundrum Sphinx attacks, each player names a card. Then each player reveals the top card of his or her library. If the card a player revealed is the card he or she named, that player puts it into his or her hand. If it's not, that player puts it on the bottom of his or her library.

cards.name: Court Hussar
cards.text:
Vigilance
When Court Hussar enters the battlefield, look at the top three cards of your library, then put one of them into your hand and the rest on the bottom of your library in any order.
When Court Hussar enters the battlefield, sacrifice it unless {W} was spent to cast it.

rulings.text: If this enters the battlefield in a way other than announcing it as a spell, then the appropriate mana can't have been paid, and you'll have to sacrifice it.

cards.originalText:
Vigilance
When Court Hussar enters the battlefield, look at the top three cards of your library, then put one of them into your hand and the rest on the bottom of your library in any order.
When Court Hussar enters the battlefield, sacrifice it unless {W} was spent to cast it.

cards.name: Dreamborn Muse
cards.text: At the beginning of each player's upkeep, that player puts the top X cards of their library into their graveyard, where X is the number of cards in their hand.
cards.flavor:
"Her voice is insight, piercing and true."
—Ixidor, reality sculptor
cards.originalText: At the beginning of each player's upkeep, that player puts the top X cards of his or her library into his or her graveyard, where X is the number of cards in his or her hand.

cards.name: Fact or Fiction
cards.text: Reveal the top five cards of your library. An opponent separates those cards into two piles. Put one pile into your hand and the other into your graveyard.
cards.flavor: "Try to pretend like you understand what's important."

rulings.text: You choose which pile to put into your hand.
Each pile may contain from zero to five cards; they don't have to be split "evenly."

cards.originalText: Reveal the top five cards of your library. An opponent separates those cards into two piles. Put one pile into your hand and the other into your graveyard.

cards.name: Flusterstorm
cards.text:
Counter target instant or sorcery spell unless its controller pays {1}.
Storm (When you cast this spell, copy it for each spell cast before it this turn. You may choose new targets for the copies.)

rulings.text: The copies are put directly onto the stack. They aren't cast and won't be counted by other spells with storm cast later in the turn.
Spells cast from zones other than a player's hand and spells that were countered are counted by the storm ability.
A copy of a spell can be countered like any other spell, but it must be countered individually. Countering a spell with storm won't affect the copies.
The triggered ability that creates the copies can itself be countered by anything that can counter a triggered ability. If it is countered, no copies will be put onto the stack.
You may choose new targets for any of the copies. You can choose differently for each copy.

cards.originalText:
Counter target instant or sorcery spell unless its controller pays {1}.
Storm (When you cast this spell, copy it for each spell cast before it this turn. You may choose new targets for the copies.)

cards.name: Fog Bank
cards.text:
Defender, flying
Prevent all combat damage that would be dealt to and dealt by Fog Bank.

rulings.text: Fog Bank's prevention effect isn't considered while assigning combat damage from a creature with trample. For example, if it blocks a 5/5 creature with trample, that creature's controller must assign 2 of that creature's combat damage to Fog Bank and the remainder can be assigned to the defending player or planeswalker.

cards.originalText:
Defender, flying
Prevent all combat damage that would be dealt to and dealt by Fog Bank.

cards.name: Gomazoa
cards.text:
Defender, flying
{T}: Put Gomazoa and each creature it's blocking on top of their owners' libraries, then those players shuffle their libraries.
cards.flavor: To explorers, "point man" is a polite way of saying "gomazoa fodder."

rulings.text: Gomazoa's ability can be activated any time its controller has priority. It doesn't need to be blocking any creatures.
If Gomazoa isn't blocking a creature at the time its ability resolves, only Gomazoa is put on top of its owner's library, and only that player shuffles their library.

cards.originalText:
Defender, flying
{T}: Put Gomazoa and each creature it's blocking on top of their owners' libraries, then those players shuffle their libraries.

cards.name: Guard Gomazoa
cards.text:
Defender, flying
Prevent all combat damage that would be dealt to Guard Gomazoa.
cards.flavor: It lingers near the outposts of the Makindi Trenches, inadvertently granting another layer of defense.
cards.originalText:
Defender, flying
Prevent all combat damage that would be dealt to Guard Gomazoa.

cards.name: Memory Erosion
cards.text: Whenever an opponent casts a spell, that player puts the top two cards of their library into their graveyard.
cards.flavor:
"The Filigree Texts do not compel you to act in accordance with their precepts. They only specify the consequences should you fail."
—Lodus of the Ethersworn
cards.originalText: Whenever an opponent casts a spell, that player puts the top two cards of his or her library into his or her graveyard.

cards.name: Minds Aglow
cards.text: Join forces — Starting with you, each player may pay any amount of mana. Each player draws X cards, where X is the total amount of mana paid this way.

rulings.text: The card-drawing part of the effect is not optional. A player can't choose to draw fewer than X cards.

cards.originalText: Join forces — Starting with you, each player may pay any amount of mana. Each player draws X cards, where X is the total amount of mana paid this way.

cards.name: Mulldrifter
cards.text:
Flying
When Mulldrifter enters the battlefield, draw two cards.
Evoke {2}{U} (You may cast this spell for its evoke cost. If you do, it's sacrificed when it enters the battlefield.)

rulings.text: Evoke is an alternative cost to cast the spell with evoke. It can't be combined with other alternative costs, such as casting a spell "without paying its mana cost."

To determine the total cost of a spell, start with the mana cost or alternative cost (such as an evoke cost) you're paying, add any cost increases, then apply any cost reductions. The converted mana cost of the spell remains unchanged, no matter what the total cost to cast it was.
If a creature with evoke enters the battlefield without being cast, you won't have to sacrifice it.
The ability that causes you to sacrifice an evoked creature is a triggered ability. Players may respond to this triggered ability while the creature is still on the battlefield.

cards.originalText:
Flying
When Mulldrifter enters the battlefield, draw two cards.
Evoke {2}{U} (You may cast this spell for its evoke cost. If you do, it's sacrificed when it enters the battlefield.)

cards.name: Murmurs from Beyond
cards.text: Reveal the top three cards of your library. An opponent chooses one of them. Put that card into your graveyard and the rest into your hand.
cards.flavor: Like pools of fog that hid treacherous rocks from sailors' eyes, so too were the hands of the kami.
cards.originalText: Reveal the top three cards of your library. An opponent chooses one of them. Put that card into your graveyard and the rest into your hand.

cards.name: Perilous Research
cards.text: Draw two cards, then sacrifice a permanent.
cards.flavor: When the School of the Unseen fell, so many magical treasures lay abandoned that no amount of death could deter the stream of thieves and desperate scholars.
cards.originalText: Draw two cards, then sacrifice a permanent.

cards.name: Propaganda
cards.text: Creatures can't attack you unless their controller pays {2} for each creature they control that's attacking you.
cards.flavor:
"You've failed Gerrard. You've failed the Legacy. You've failed yourself. I can do no more."
—Volrath, to Karn

rulings.text: The payment is made during the declare attackers step at the same time you are declaring the attacker.
If there is more than one Propaganda on the battlefield, the cost is cumulative.
If there are multiple attacks in a turn, then you have to pay for each attack.
Paying this cost is not an instant or any other kind of ability, it is an additional cost on the declaration of the attacker.
In the Two-Headed Giant format, you still only have to pay once per creature.
Unless some effect explicitly says otherwise, a creature that can't attack you can still attack a planeswalker you control.

cards.originalText: Creatures can't attack you unless their controller pays {2} for each creature he or she controls that's attacking you.

cards.name: Ray of Command
cards.text: Untap target creature an opponent controls and gain control of it until end of turn. That creature gains haste until end of turn. When you lose control of the creature, tap it.
cards.flavor: "Heel."

rulings.text: You may target an untapped creature with Ray of Command.

The creature returns to the opponent when the "until end of turn" effect wears off during the cleanup step. It taps during the Cleanup step (if it is not already tapped), so any abilities triggered off it tapping happen at that time.
You tap the creature when you lose control of it for any reason — because Ray of Command's effect ends, or because a spell or ability causes another player to gain control of it.

cards.originalText: Untap target creature an opponent controls and gain control of it until end of turn. That creature gains haste until end of turn. When you lose control of the creature, tap it.

cards.name: Reins of Power
cards.text: Untap all creatures you control and all creatures target opponent controls. You and that opponent each gain control of all creatures the other controls until end of turn. Those creatures gain haste until end of turn.

rulings.text: It is perfectly legal for either or both players to have zero creatures. They give control of all their zero creatures as instructed.
You only untap creatures controlled by you and the targeted opponent, not all creatures.

cards.originalText: Untap all creatures you control and all creatures target opponent controls. You and that opponent each gain control of all creatures the other controls until end of turn. Those creatures gain haste until end of turn.

cards.name: Repulse
cards.text:
Return target creature to its owner's hand.
Draw a card.
cards.flavor: "You aren't invited."
cards.originalText:
Return target creature to its owner's hand.
Draw a card.

cards.name: Riddlekeeper
cards.text: Whenever a creature attacks you or a planeswalker you control, that creature's controller puts the top two cards of their library into their graveyard.
cards.flavor: Fools surrender their sanity to his riddles. Even greater fools try to solve them.

rulings.text: Riddlekeeper doesn't impose a cost to attack. Creatures can attack you or a planeswalker you control even if their controller has no cards left in their library.

cards.originalText: Whenever a creature attacks you or a planeswalker you control, that creature's controller puts the top two cards of his or her library into his or her graveyard.

cards.name: Scattering Stroke
cards.text: Counter target spell. Clash with an opponent. If you win, at the beginning of your next main phase, you may add an amount of {C} equal to that spell's converted mana cost. (Each clashing player reveals the top card of their library, then puts that card on the top or bottom. A player wins if their card had a higher converted mana cost.)

rulings.text: You decide whether or not to add that much {C} to your mana pool as the delayed triggered ability resolves at the beginning of your next main phase. You don't decide before then.
You can't add just some of the mana to your mana pool. You either add all the mana to your mana pool or none of it.

cards.originalText: Counter target spell. Clash with an opponent. If you win, at the beginning of your next main phase, you may add {X} to your mana pool, where X is that spell's converted mana cost. (Each clashing player reveals the top card of his or her library, then puts that card on the top or bottom. A player wins if his or her card had a higher converted mana cost.)

cards.name: Skyscribing
cards.text:
Each player draws X cards.
Forecast — {2}{U}, Reveal Skyscribing from your hand: Each player draws a card. (Activate this ability only during your upkeep and only once each turn.)
cards.originalText:
Each player draws X cards.
Forecast — {2}{U}, Reveal Skyscribing from your hand: Each player draws a card. (Activate this ability only during your upkeep and only once each turn.)

cards.name: Slipstream Eel
cards.text:
Slipstream Eel can't attack unless defending player controls an Island.
Cycling {1}{U} ({1}{U}, Discard this card: Draw a card.)
cards.flavor: "It's a fine way to travel, if you don't mind the smell."

rulings.text: Cycling is an activated ability. Effects that interact with activated abilities (such as Stifle or Rings of Brighthearth) will interact with cycling. Effects that interact with spells (such as Remove Soul or Faerie Tauntings) will not.

cards.originalText:
Slipstream Eel can't attack unless defending player controls an Island.
Cycling {1}{U} ({1}{U}, Discard this card: Draw a card.)

cards.name: Spell Crumple
cards.text: Counter target spell. If that spell is countered this way, put it on the bottom of its owner's library instead of into that player's graveyard. Put Spell Crumple on the bottom of its owner's library.

rulings.text: If the spell is an illegal target when Spell Crumple tries to resolve, it won't resolve and none of its effects will happen. Spell Crumple will be put into its owner's graveyard.
If the targeted spell can't be countered, it won't be put onto the bottom of its owner's library. Spell Crumple will still be put on the bottom of its owner's library.

cards.originalText: Counter target spell. If that spell is countered this way, put it on the bottom of its owner's library instead of into that player's graveyard. Put Spell Crumple on the bottom of its owner's library.

cards.name: Trade Secrets
cards.text: Target opponent draws two cards, then you draw up to four cards. That opponent may repeat this process as many times as they choose.
cards.originalText: Target opponent draws two cards, then you draw up to four cards. That opponent may repeat this process as many times as he or she chooses.

cards.name: Trench Gorger
cards.text:
Trample
When Trench Gorger enters the battlefield, you may search your library for any number of land cards, exile them, then shuffle your library. If you do, Trench Gorger has base power and base toughness each equal to the number of cards exiled this way.

rulings.text: If you choose not to search, Trench Gorger will simply be 6/6.
While Trench Gorger's ability is on the stack, it's on the battlefield as a 6/6.
If Trench Gorger leaves the battlefield before its triggered ability resolves, you may still search your library.
After the ability resolves, Trench Gorger's power and toughness won't change if one of the exiled cards leaves exile.

cards.originalText:
Trample
When Trench Gorger enters the battlefield, you may search your library for any number of land cards, exile them, then shuffle your library. If you do, Trench Gorger's power and toughness each become equal to the number of cards exiled this way.

cards.name: Vedalken Plotter
cards.text: When Vedalken Plotter enters the battlefield, exchange control of target land you control and target land an opponent controls.
cards.flavor: "Fair? At what point in our negotiations did you convince yourself my goal was to be fair?"

rulings.text: If either land becomes an illegal target (or leaves the battlefield) before the ability resolves, the exchange won't happen. There's no way for you to gain a land without losing another one in the process.

foreignNames.name: ヴィダルケンの策謀者

cards.originalText: When Vedalken Plotter enters the battlefield, exchange control of target land you control and target land an opponent controls.

cards.name: Vision Skeins
cards.text: Each player draws two cards.
cards.flavor: "I could see in the other mage's eyes that he'd thought of it too. Then it became a race to exploit the knowledge first."
cards.originalText: Each player draws two cards.

cards.name: Vow of Flight
cards.text:
Enchant creature
Enchanted creature gets +2/+2, has flying, and can't attack you or a planeswalker you control.
cards.flavor:
"Soaring is wasted on the winged."
—Edric, Spymaster of Trest
cards.originalText:
Enchant creature
Enchanted creature gets +2/+2, has flying, and can't attack you or a planeswalker you control.

cards.name: Whirlpool Whelm
cards.text: Clash with an opponent, then return target creature to its owner's hand. If you win, you may put that creature on top of its owner's library instead. (Each clashing player reveals the top card of their library, then puts that card on the top or bottom. A player wins if their card had a higher converted mana cost.)

rulings.text: You choose the target when you play Whirlpool Whelm, not when you clash.
If you don't win the clash, the targeted creature always goes to its owner's hand. If you win the clash, you choose whether the creature goes to its owner's hand or the top of its owner's library.

If you clash with the owner of the targeted creature and win, the owner of the creature decides where to put to card revealed during the clash before you decide whether to put the creature on top of that library. You know the player's decision before you make your decision.

cards.originalText: Clash with an opponent, then return target creature to its owner's hand. If you win, you may put that creature on top of its owner's library instead. (Each clashing player reveals the top card of his or her library, then puts that card on the top or bottom. A player wins if his or her card had a higher converted mana cost.)

cards.name: Windfall
cards.text: Each player discards their hand, then draws cards equal to the greatest number of cards a player discarded this way.
cards.flavor:
"To fill your mind with knowledge, we must start by emptying it."
—Barrin, master wizard
cards.originalText: Each player discards his or her hand, then draws cards equal to the greatest number of cards a player discarded this way.

cards.name: Wonder
cards.text:
Flying
As long as Wonder is in your graveyard and you control an Island, creatures you control have flying.
cards.flavor:
"The awestruck birds gazed at Wonder. Slowly, timidly, they rose into the air."
—Scroll of Beginnings
cards.originalText:
Flying
As long as Wonder is in your graveyard and you control an Island, creatures you control have flying.
